page.title: Faculty of Translation and Interpreting of the University of Geneva

revision.text: {{peacock|date=April 2017}} {{Infobox university | name = Faculty of Translation and Interpreting (FTI) | native_name = Faculté de traduction et d'interprétation (FTI) | native_name_lang = fr | former_name = School of Translation and Interpreting (ETI) | established = 1941 | type = public | parent = [[University of Geneva]] in [[Switzerland]] | language = Arabic, English, French, German, Italian, Spanish and Russian | colours = {{color box|orange}} Orange | coordinates = {{Coord|46|11|41|N|6|08|25|E|type:edu_region:MX-DIF|display=inline,title}} | pushpin_map = Switzerland | pushpin_map_caption = Geographical location of the Faculty of Translation and Interpreting (FTI) | city = [[Geneva]] | country = [[Switzerland]] | location = [[Switzerland]]/[[Geneva]]/Republic and [[Canton of Geneva]]/World | founder = Antoine Velleman | website = {{URL|http://www.unige.ch/fti}} }} The '''Faculty of Translation and Interpreting''' (FTI) is a faculty of the [[University of Geneva]] in Switzerland. == Introduction == [[File:UniMail-batiment-claire.jpg|thumb|The FTI is located on the sixth floor of the University of Geneva’s Uni Mail building.]] The Faculty of Translation and Interpreting (FTI) is one of the oldest translation and interpreting education and research institutions in the world. It was founded in 1941, by Antoine Velleman, as the Ecole d’interprètes de Genève (EIG). When a translation degree was introduced in 1972, it became the École de traduction et d’interprétation (School of Translation and Interpreting - ETI), before adopting its current title – Faculty of Translation and Interpreting – in 2011. {{Quote|text="Mr. Velleman was more than qualified to set up and direct the school, which he predicted would expand rapidly as Switzerland prepared itself for post-war recovery. Furthermore, Geneva, with its tradition of international collaboration, offered plenty of advantages to successfully bring about such a project. Before the Second World War, only one other school of its kind existed – a school that was founded in 1930 in Mannheim by Swiss professor Dr. Charles Glauser and was attached to the University of Heidelberg in 1936."|author=S. Stelling-Michaud|title=L’École d’interprètes de 1941 à 1956.}} Initially a part of the Faculty of Humanities, the EIG broke away from the Faculty between 1953-1955, and eventually became an independent institution of the [[University of Geneva|university]].{{sfn|Martin|1958|p=296}} Today, the FTI has over a hundred teachers and researchers. == Location == Up until 1946, the school’s administrative offices were located in Antoine Velleman’s office at 5 Avenue Marc-Monnier,{{sfn|Capel Esteve|Chazal|2010}} then in an apartment at 4 Rue Saint-Victor. Three rooms and the hallway were used for the school, while three other rooms were reserved for administrative purposes. From 1952–1953, the University was renovated and the school’s administrative offices were set up on the former premises of the physics institute (ground floor). In 1978, the school moved to the Cours Commerciaux de Genève building at 19 Place des Augustins. It then moved to the new Uni Mail building at 40 Boulevard du Pont-d'Arve in 1992.{{sfn|Capel Esteve|Chazal|2010}} == Resources and services == Students have access to [[IT]] and audiovisual resources, as well as a library specialized in [[translation studies]], [[translation]] (theory, history, education, etc.), [[language interpretation|consecutive and simultaneous interpreting]], [[sign language]] interpreting, [[computational linguistics]], [[terminology]] and [[lexicology]]. === Library === The FTI library is located on the second floor of Uni-Mail. Students can consult and take out books on subjects taught at the FTI, specialized and language dictionaries, and journals.{{sfn|Duret|1998a|p=4}} Since 1984, the library has been a part of [[RERO (Réseau romand)|RERO]], a network of libraries in Western Switzerland.{{sfn|Duret|1998b|p=34}} It uses the [[Dewey Decimal Classification|Dewey Decimal System]].{{sfn|Duret|1998a|p=4}} The first FTI library was made up of Antoine Velleman’s own personal collection of works, which he kept in his office on Avenue Marc-Monnier and would lend out to students. {{Quote|text="Antoine Velleman made his library available to the first students, who – with much emotion – recall learning things from dictionaries, books and journals annotated in Velleman’s own hand. For years, there was no one there in that room… We had the key to the library (several of us were almost always gathered around the table), no one monitored us. And I don’t think many of those books disappeared…"|author=Gérard Ilg|title=cited in Duret.{{sfn|Duret|1998b|pp=11-12}}}} In 1953, a room in the basement of the Bastions building on Rue de Candolle was converted into a library.{{sfn|Duret|1998b|p=21}}{{sfn|Duret|1998b|p=11}} The library truly became specialized, providing access to a collection of dictionaries (monolingual, bilingual, technical) and documents on the [[International Organizations]].{{sfn|Duret|1998b|p=21}} When the school moved to the Cours Commerciaux de Genève building in 1978, the library was equipped with computers, cassette tapes containing interpreting exercises and CD-ROMs.{{sfn|Duret|1998b|p=34}} === Simultaneous interpreting === Antoine Velleman was not in favour of simultaneous interpreting and so, initially, only consecutive interpreting classes were offered by the school. Graduates of the programme took it upon themselves to organize simultaneous interpreting training sessions in the evenings. The school’s alumni association (AAEDEI) contacted [[International Business Machines|IBM]] to set up an interpreting booth. The training sessions took place in a room rented on the ground floor of a Methodist church at 12 Rue Calvin. Sessions took place regularly from 1947 onwards. Each participant had to pay three francs per session in order to cover the cost of constructing the booth and renting the room. It was not until 1950 that the first simultaneous interpreting classes were officially offered at the school by Serge Gloor.{{sfn|Rumprecht|2008}} In 1952, the school acquired simultaneous interpreting equipment, thanks to a donation from IBM. On 4 February 1953, a new simultaneous interpreting training room was inaugurated in the basement of Uni Bastions.{{sfn|Duret|1998b|p=15}} The room was equipped with ten booths and a control box, which was integrated into the teacher’s desk, allowing the teacher to monitor each booth. Today, the Faculty has a virtual teaching platform that allows simultaneous interpreting to be taught at a distance. The application gives users access to digitized [[Public speaking|speeches]], a [[Internet forum|forum]], a [[Online chat|chat]] system and a space for teachers to give feedback to students. Students can listen back to the original speech as well as their interpretation of it.{{sfn|Moussadek|2007}} == FTI Programmes == The Faculty offers the following programmes: [[Bachelor of Arts]] in Multilingual Communication, [[Master of Arts]] in Translation, Master of Arts in Conference Interpreting,Graduates of the FTI are among the best interpreters in the world, according to an article in The Monocle Forecast, {{citation |language=en |issue=43 |author=Ed Stocker |title=Strong Language |periodical=The Monocle Forecast |year=2016 |pages=38–43}} Complementary Certificate in Translation. Students make up their language combination based on the languages offered by the Faculty, which are [[German language|German]], [[English language|English]], [[Arabic language|Arabic]], [[Spanish language|Spanish]], [[French language|French]], [[Italian language|Italian]] and [[Russian language|Russian]]. Besides translation and conference interpreting, the programmes offered by the Faculty can lead to careers in [[Wikipedia:Multilingual communication|multilingual communication]], [[public relations]], the [[mass media|media]], [[public administration]], [[tourism]], the [[court]] system, language mediation services, [[education]] and [[research]]. == Exchange programmes == The FTI has exchange agreements with 70 universities in over 20 countries. == Research == In the first few years of its existence, the school was mostly geared towards professional training, but today, it carries out research in a variety of different fields. === Research groups === FTI’s research groups are currently leading projects financed by the [[European Union]] and the [[Swiss National Science Foundation]]. The Centre for Legal and Institutional Translation Studies (Transius) specializes in [[Legal translation|legal]] and institutional translation.{{Cite web|url=http://transius.unige.ch/en/|title=Centre for Legal and Institutional Translation Studies (Transius) - Transius - UNIGE|website=transius.unige.ch|language=en|access-date=2017-04-28}} The "Economics, Languages and Education" research group (Observatoire élf) looks into [[Language Management|linguistic diversity management]].{{Cite web|url=http://www.unige.ch/traduction-interpretation/recherches/groupes/elf.html|title=Observatoire élf - Observatoire élf - UNIGE|website=www.unige.ch|language=fr|access-date=2017-04-28}} The Department of Translation Technology (TIM) works with [[Machine translation|translation technology]], [[speech recognition]] in language learning, terminology and lexicology.{{Cite web|url=http://www.unige.ch/traduction-interpretation/faculte/organisation/departements/dtim_en.html|title=The Department of Translation Technology (TIM)|website=www.unige.ch|language=en|access-date=2017-04-28}} The Interpreting Department carries out projects on interpreting, [[cognition]] and [[Humanitarian aid|humanitarian]] aspects of interpreting.{{Cite web|url=http://www.unige.ch/traduction-interpretation/faculte/organisation/departements/uint_en.html|title=The Interpreting Department|website=www.unige.ch|language=en|access-date=2017-04-28}} === PhD Programme === The FTI has a PhD programme with specializations in translation studies, multilingual information processing, conference interpreting, and multilingual communication management. == Local and international relations == === Continuing education === The FTI offers [[continuing education]] degree and certificate programmes in translation studies, translation methodology, translation (financial, legal, technical and literary), writing (active and passive languages), [[technical writing]], [[computer-assisted translation]], terminology and interpreting. === European and international networks === The FTI is a member of a number of European and international networks, including: * UN University Outreach Programme; * European Masters in Conference Interpreting (EMCI); * [[European Master's in Translation|European Masters in Translation]] (EMT); * Conférence internationale permanente d'instituts universitaires de traducteurs et interprètes (CIUTI); * Universities Contact Group of the International Annual Meeting on Language Arrangements, Documentation and Publications (IAMLADP). === Technological innovation === The FTI collaborates with the city of Geneva on technologically innovative projects. BabelDr, a collaboration between the FTI and [[Geneva University Hospitals|Geneva's University Hospitals]], won the Innogap prize in 2015.{{citation needed|date=April 2017}} == Notes and references == {{Reflist|30em|refs= {{citation |type=book|last=Stelling-Michaud|first=S.|year=1959|chapter=L’École d’interprètes de 1941 à 1956|title=Histoire de l’Université de Genève|publisher=Georg|page=317|language =fr}} {{citation|type=article|last=Namy |first =Claude | title= La réforme de l’École d’interprètes de Genève | journal = L’interprète | volume = 28 | page = 4| issue = 2-3 | year = 1973 | language = fr}} {{citation|type=article| last =Stelling-Michaud | first =S. | title = 15 mai 1875 - 16 mai 1975. Antoine Velleman. Fondateur de l'École d'interprètes | journal = L’interprète | volume = 30 | issue = 4 | page = 4| year = 1975 | language = fr}} {{citation|type=chapter|language=fr |title=Dictionnaire historique de la Suisse |chapter=Traductions |url=http://www.hls-dhs-dss.ch/textes/f/F30728.php |access-date = March 19, 2016}} {{citation|type=article| last =Velleman | first =Antoine | title = L'École d'interprètes de l'Université de Genève | journal = Die Friedens-Warte | volume = 43 | issue = 3-4 | page = 167| year = 1943 | language = fr}} {{citation|type=article| last =Kaiser | first =Walter | title = L’interprétation de conférence en tant que profession et les précurseurs de l’Association Internationale des Interprètes de Conférence (AIIC) 1918-1953 | journal = Meta: journal des traducteurs | volume = 49 | issue = 3 [L’histoire de la traduction et la traduction de l’histoire] | page = 579| year = 2004 | language = fr}} {{citation |type=book| last=Gaiba|first=Francesca|year=1998|title=The Origins of Simultaneous Interpretation: The Nuremberg Trial|publisher=University of Ottawa Press|page=28| language =en}} {{citation |type=book|last=van Hoof|first=Henri|year=1991|title=Histoire de la traduction en Occident: France, Grande-Bretagne, Allemagne, Russie, Pays-Bas|publisher=Duculot|page=116| language =fr}} {{citation |type=book |last=Millán|first=Carmen|last2=Bartrina|first2=Francesca|year=1998|title=The Routledge Handbook of Translation Studies|publisher=Routledge|page=365| language =en}} {{citation|type=article| last =Namy | first =Claude | title = La réforme de l’École d’interprètes de Genève | journal = L’interprète | volume = 28 | issue = 2-3 | page = 5| year = 1973 | language = fr}} {{citation|type=article|language=fr|author=Louis Truffaut|title=L’ETI va souffler ses cinquante bougies|periodical=Campus (Magazine de l’Université de Genève)|issue=9|date=April–May 1991|pages=32–33}} {{citation |type=book |last=Geisendorf |first=Paul-Frédéric |year=1959 |title=L'Université de Genève: 1559-1959 |place=Genève |page=294| language =fr}} {{cite web |language=fr |url=http://www.unige.ch/traduction-interpretation/faculte/enseignants-collaborateurs/liste-corps-enseignant.html |title= Faculté de traduction et d'interprétation - Corps académique |website=unige.ch |access-date= March 19, 2016}} {{citation|type=chapter |last=Stelling-Michaud|first=S.|year=1959|chapter=L’École d’interprètes de 1941 à 1956|title=Histoire de l’Université de Genève |publisher=Georg |page=318 | language =fr}} {{cite web |language=en |url=http://www.unige.ch/traduction-interpretation/enseignements/formations_en.html |title=Faculty of Translation and Interpreting - Programmes on offer |website=unige.ch |access-date= March 20, 2016}} {{cite web |language=fr |url=http://www.unige.ch/traduction-interpretation/enseignements/mobilite-echanges/universites-partenaires.html |title=Faculté de traduction et d'interprétation - Universités partenaires |website=unige.ch |access-date= March 20, 2016}} {{citation |last=Marcacci|first=Marco|year=1987|chapter=La vie des facultés et des instituts: permanences, changements, protagonistes |title=Histoire de l'Université de Genève: 1559-1986|publisher=Université de Genève|page=215|language =fr}} {{cite web |language=en |url= http://www.emcinterpreting.org |title=European Masters in Conference Interpreting |origyear=2013–2014 |accessdate= March 20, 2016|website=emcinterpreting.org}} {{cite web |language=fr |url=http://ec.europa.eu/dgs/translation/programmes/emt/universities/index_fr.htm |title=Universities and programmes in the EMT network |date= November 26, 2014 |publisher=Directorate-General for Translation of the European Commission|access-date= March 20, 2016}} {{cite web |language=en |url= http://www.ciuti.org/members/ |title=Members | access-date=March 20, 2016|publisher=Conférence internationale permanente d'instituts universitaires de traducteurs et interprètes}} }} == Bibliography == === Books === *{{cite book |language=fr |first=Carmen M. |last=Capel Esteve |first2=Axelle|last2=Chazal |title=Les études en interprétation de conférence à l'ETI: Avant, pendant et après |place=Geneva |publisher=University of Geneva |type=dissertation for the Master of Arts in Conference Interpreting |year=2010}} *{{cite book |language=fr |first=Patrice|last=Duret |title=L'École de traduction et d'interprétation et sa bibliothèque (1941-1993): dossiers documentaires et brochure historique: rapport |type=final-year project |place=Geneva |publisher=Association des bibliothèques et bibliothécaires suisses |year=1998a}} *{{cite book |language=fr |first=Patrice|last=Duret |title=L'ETI: toute une histoire... L'École de traduction et d'interprétation de 1941 à 1993 |type=unpublished final-year project |place=Geneva |publisher=Bibliothèque de l'École de traduction et d'interprétation |year=1998b}} *{{cite book |language=fr |first=Paul-Edmond|last=Martin |title=L'Université de 1914 à 1956 |place= Geneva |year=1958 |chapter=XXXII - L’école d'interprètes (1948-1955) |pages=293–296}} *{{cite book |type=chapter |language=de |first=Katrin|last=Rumprecht |chapter=Die Nürnberger Prozesse und ihre Bedeutung für die Entwicklung des modernen Konferenzdolmetschens |issue=5.1 (École de Traduction et Interprétation (ETI) in Genf) |editor=Hartwig Kalverkämper and Larisa Schippel (dir.) |title=Simultandolmetschen in Erstbewährung: Der Nürnberger Prozess 1945 |place=Berlin |publisher=Frank & Timme |year=2008 |pages=264–265}} *{{cite book |language=de |publisher=Schweiz. Zentralstelle für Frauenberufe |title=Die Dolmetscherschule in Genf |year=1943}} === Articles === *{{citation |language=fr |author=Bruno de Bessé |title=École de traduction et d’interprétation de l’Université de Genève |periodical=Traduire: revue française de la traduction |issue=192 |year=2002 |pages=53–67}} *{{citation |language=fr |author=Louis Truffaut |title=L’École de traduction et d’interprétation de l’Université de Genève |periodical=Cahiers européens - Europäische Hefte - Notes from Europe |issue=2 |year=1980 |pages=82–96}} * {{citation |language=fr |author=Françoise Buffat |title=Y a-t-il une crise à l'École de traduction et d'interprétation ? |periodical=[[Journal de Genève]] |date= July 11, 1977}} * {{citation |language=fr |author=Varuna Singh |title=Le diplôme de l'Ecole de traduction devient eurocompatible |periodical=[[Journal de Genève]] et [[Gazette de Lausanne]] |date=July 15, 1993}} * {{citation |language=fr |author=Claudine Girod |title=La "réforme" de l'École de traduction sème la discorde |periodical=[[Tribune de Genève]] |date= August 26, 2004}} * {{citation |language=fr |author=Yvan Schulz |title=L’ETI peine à faire passer ses réformes |periodical=[[Le Courrier]] |date=December 22, 2004}} * {{citation |language=fr |author=Miguel Otera |title=L’ETI veut faire la preuve par dix de l’efficacité de ses réformes |periodical=[[Le Courrier]] |date= February 28, 2005}} *{{citation | language=fr |first=Marion|last=Moussadek |title=À l’ère digitale, le métier d’interprète de conférence amorce sa mutation |periodical=[[Le Temps (quotidien suisse)|Le Temps]] |date= May 4, 2007}} == External links == *[http://www.unige.ch/traduction-interpretation/index_en.html Official website of the FTI] *[http://aetiunige.wordpress.com/ Website of the Association of Translation and Interpreting students (AETI) (in French)] * [http://mastertranslation.ch/ Master’s in Translation] {{Portal bar|Geneva|Switzerland|University}} [[Category:University of Geneva faculty|.]] [[Category:Translation organizations]] [[Category:Interpretation organizations]] [[Category:University of Geneva]]

{{Infobox artwork| image_size = 300px| image=Faustulus - Mosaic de Font de Mussa - Museu de Prehistòria de València.JPG | title=Mosaic de la Font de Mussa | caption = Detail of the Mosaic, with [[Faustulus]] represented. | artist=Unknown | year=approx. [[1st century|1st]]-[[2nd century]] Discovered in 2001 in [[Font de Mussa]] ([[Benifaió]]) | type = [[Mosaic]] | medium = [[Marble]] | height_metric = 550 | width_metric = 425 | height_imperial = <!-- (i.e. in imperial units) --> | width_imperial = | length_imperial = | museum= [[Prehistory Museum of Valencia]] |city = [[Valencia]] |condition= }} The '''Mosaic de la Font de Mussa''' (''Mosaic from the Source of Mussa'', in [[English language|English]]) is a [[Roman Empire|Roman]] [[mosaic]] found in [[Benifaió]] ([[Ribera Alta (comarca)|Ribera Alta]], [[Land of Valencia]]) and that dates of the 1st or 2nd century.<ref name=":0">{{Cite book|last = |first = |title = El mosaico romano de "los orígenes de Roma"|url = |edition = |language = |date = 2004|publisher = Ed. Laia|place = Barcelona|pages = 134|isbn = 8493337145}}</ref> It is located into the [[Prehistory Museum of Valencia|Museum of Prehistory of Valencia]], where is one of the most highlighted pieces.<ref>{{Cite book|surname = Bonet Rosado|first = Helena|title = Romans i visigots a les terres valencianes|url = http://www.museuprehistoriavalencia.es/web_mupreva/publicaciones/?q=va&id=249|edition = |language = |date = 2003|publisher = [[Museu de Prehistòria de València]]|place = Valencia|pages = 302|isbn = 84-7795-340-6|surname2 = Albiach Descals|first2 = Rosa|first3 = Manuel|surname3 = Gozalbes Fernández de Palencia}}</ref>
Its a [[Roman mosaic|mosaic]] of ''[[opus tessellatum]]'' decorated with tesselles of marble of 6 millimeters.<ref name=":0" />
It presents a central decoration [[Polychrome|polychromated]] showing figures that represents the shepherd [[Faustulus]] and his brother in front of a cave where there is a wolf that would suckle to [[Romulus and Remus]].<ref name=":0" />
== References == <references></references>

[[File:Garganornis ballmanni (reconstruction by Stefano Maugeri).jpg|thumb|''[[Garganornis ballmanni]]'', a very large fossil goose from the Gargano and Scontrone islands of the [[Late Miocene]]]] '''Foster's rule''', also known as the '''island rule''' or the '''island effect''', is an [[ecogeographical rule]] in [[evolutionary biology]] stating that members of a [[species]] get smaller or bigger depending on the resources available in the environment. For example, it is known that [[pygmy mammoth]]s evolved from normal [[mammoth]]s on small [[island]]s. Similar evolutionary paths have been observed in [[elephant]]s, [[hippopotamus]]es, [[Boidae|boa]]s, [[deer]] (such as [[Key deer]]) and [[human]]s.<ref>Juan Luis Arsuaga, Andy Klatt, ''The Neanderthal's Necklace: In Search of the First Thinkers'', Thunder's Mouth Press, 2004, {{ISBN|1-56858-303-6}}, {{ISBN|978-1-56858-303-7}}, p. 199.</ref><ref>Jean-Baptiste de Panafieu, Patrick Gries, ''Evolution'', Seven Stories Press, 2007, {{ISBN|1-58322-784-9}}, {{ISBN|978-1-58322-784-8}}, p 42.</ref>
The rule was first stated by J. Bristol Foster in 1964.<ref>{{cite journal | last=Foster | first=J.B. | year=1964 | title=The evolution of mammals on islands | journal=Nature | volume=202 | pages=234–235| doi=10.1038/202234a0 | bibcode=1964Natur.202..234F | issue=4929 }}</ref><ref>Foster, J. B. (1965) The evolution of the mammals of the Queen Charlotte Islands, British Columbia. ''Occasional Papers of the British Columbia Provincial Museum'', '''14''', 1–130.</ref> In it, he compared 116 island species to their mainland varieties. He proposed that certain island creatures evolved into [[insular gigantism|larger versions of themselves (insular gigantism)]] while others became [[insular dwarfism|smaller versions of themselves (insular dwarfism)]]. He proposed the simple explanation that smaller creatures get larger when predation pressure is relaxed because of the absence of some of the predators of the mainland, and larger creatures become smaller when food resources are limited because of land area constraints.<ref>{{cite book | first=R.J. | last=Whittaker | title=Island biogeography: ecology, evolution, and conservation | publisher=Oxford University Press, UK | year=1998 | isbn=978-0-19-850020-9 | pages=73–75 }}</ref>
The idea was expanded upon in ''[[The Theory of Island Biogeography]]'', by [[Robert MacArthur]] and [[Edward O. Wilson]]. In 1978, Ted J. Case published a longer paper on the topic in the journal ''[[Ecology (journal)|Ecology]]''.<ref>{{cite journal | last=Case | first=T.J. | year=1978 | title=A general explanation for insular body size trends in terrestrial vertebrates | journal=Ecology | volume=59 | pages=1–18 | doi=10.2307/1936628 | issue=1 }}</ref>
== References == {{reflist}}
== External links == * "[https://www.pbs.org/wgbh/nova/eden/giants.html Why Do Islands Breed Giants (And Sometimes Dwarfs)?]", episode of PBS's ''Nova''

revision.text:
{{Underlinked|date=August 2014}}
The '''Hans Kilian Award''' honors researchers whose outstanding scientific achievements provide a deeper insight into the historical and cultural existence of humankind and the changing human psyche.
The award was conceived by [[:de: Lotte Köhler|Lotte Köhler]] and established by the Köhler Foundation. It bears the name of the late social psychologist and psychoanalyst [[:de: Hans Kilian|Hans Kilian]] (1921-2008) and aims to foster his idea of an interdisciplinary social psychology and psychoanalysis as well as his concept of "metacultural humanization." This concept reflects the interactions between individual life history and broader sociohistorical developments and aims to integrate social and cultural psychological, psychoanalytic, anthropological, historical, and sociological perspectives.
In line with Hans Kilian's ideas, the award recognizes international scientific achievements that cross the boundaries between disciplines and cultures and create productive syntheses between previously isolated areas of knowledge. Desirable inter- and transdisciplinary perspectives combine theories, methods, and findings from a wide spectrum of disciplines including the humanities, the social sciences, and cultural studies, as well as psychiatry and other areas of medicine. Amounting to 80,000 euros, the Hans Kilian Award is one of the best-endowed social sciences awards in Europe. It is awarded every two years and was first awarded in 2011.
The award will be a central part of the activities of the [[Hans Kilian and Lotte Köhler Center]] (KKC) for Social and Cultural Scientific Psychology and Historical Anthropology which was founded by the Köhler Foundation in August 2014 and whose office and activities are based at the Chair of Social Theory and Social Psychology, Ruhr University Bochum, Germany.
== Awardees == * 2011: Professor Dr. [[:de:Hartmut Böhme|Hartmut Böhme]] * 2013: Professor Dr. [[Hans Joas]] * 2015: Professor Dr. [[Jessica Benjamin]] * 2017: Professor Dr. [[Jaan Valsiner]] <gallery> File:Pressebild Hans-Kilian-Preisverleihung 06. Mai 2011 in Darmstadt.jpg|2011: Hartmut Böhme, Lotte Köhler, Ambros Schindler File:Pressebild Hans-Kilian-Preisverleihung 20. Juni 2013 in Bochum.jpg|2013: Lotte Köhler, Hans Joas, Ambros Schindler File:Jessica R. Benjamin, Vorstandvorsitzender Wolfgang Mertens.jpg|2015: Jessica R. Benjamin, Wolfgang Mertens File:Hans-kilian-preis 3291.jpg|2017: Heinz-Rudi Spiegel, Jaan Valsiner, Wolfgang Mertens </gallery>
== External links == * [http://www.hans-kilian-preis.de/en/starting-page.html Hans-Kilian-Award] * [http://stiftungen.stifterverband.info/s112_koehler/index.html Köhler-Stiftung] * [http://www.stifterverband.info/ueber_den_stifterverband/english/index.html Stifterverband für die Deutsche Wissenschaft] * [http://www.sowi.rub.de/soztheo/ Chair of Social Theory and Social Psychology]
[[Category:Social sciences awards]]

revision.text:
{{Expand Swedish|Hemmafru|date=June 2016}} [[File:Tyranov - Young Housewife.jpg|thumb|''Young Housewife'', Oil on canvas, by [[Alexey Tyranov]] (1801–1859), in the [[Russian Museum]], [[Saint Petersburg|St Petersburg]], [[Russia]]]]
A '''housewife''' (also known as a '''homekeeper''') is a woman whose work is running or managing her family's home—caring for her [[children]]; buying, [[cooking]], and [[Food preservation|storing]] food for the family; buying [[Good (economics)|goods]] that the family needs in everyday life; [[housekeeping]] and maintaining the home; and [[Sewing|making]] clothes for the family—and who is not employed outside the home.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.macmillandictionary.com/dictionary/american/housewife|website= Macmillan Dictionary |title=Housewife}}</ref> A housewife may also be called a '''stay-at-home mother'''<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.stayathomemum.com.au|website=StayAtHomeMum|title=Home page}}</ref> and a househusband may be called a "male homemaker" or [[stay-at-home dad|stay-at-home father]].
''[[Webster's Dictionary]]'' describes a housewife as a married woman who is in charge of her [[household]]. The British ''Chambers's Twentieth Century Dictionary'' (1901) defined a housewife as: "the mistress of a household; a female domestic manager; a pocket sewing kit".<ref>{{cite book|author=Davidson, Thomas (ed.)|title=Chambers's Twentieth Century Dictionary of the English Language|location=London|publisher= W. & R. Chambers|page=443}}</ref> A small sewing kit is sometimes called a "housewife" or "'''hussif'''".<ref>{{OED|housewife|id=88947}}</ref>
Throughout history, women have usually worked for pay, either by contributing to farming and other family-owned businesses or working for other employers. Housewives were common in developed countries only for a few decades during the middle of the 20th century.<ref name=":0" />
==Sociology and economics== [[File:Good housekeeping 1908 08 a.jpg|thumb|''Good Housekeeping'' (an American magazine), 1908]] [[Image:Southern Paiutes.jpg|thumb|Southern [[Paiutes]] at [[Moapa River Indian Reservation|Moapa]], Nevada, wearing traditional Paiute basket hats; note the Paiute cradleboard and rabbit robe]] Some feminists<ref name="Luxton1">{{Citation | last1 = Luxton | first1 = Meg | last2 = Rosenberg | first2 = Harriet | title = Through the Kitchen Window: The Politics of Home and Family | publisher = Garamond Press | year = 1986 | isbn = 978-0-920059-30-2 }}</ref><ref name="Luxton2">{{Citation | last1 = Luxton | first1 = Meg | title = More Than a Labour of Love: Three Generations of Women's Work in the Home | publisher = Women's Press | year = 1980 | isbn = 978-0-88961-062-0}}</ref> and non-feminist [[economist]]s (particularly proponents of [[historical materialism]], the methodological approach of [[Marxist historiography]]) note that the value of housewives' work is ignored in standard formulations of economic output, such as [[GDP]] or [[employment]] figures. Housewives work many unpaid hours a week, often depending on income from their husband's employment for financial support.
===Traditional societies=== [[File:The National Archives UK - CO 1069-46-45.jpg|thumb|A housewife in Yendi, [[Kumasi]], Ghana, pours water into a meal and her children play; 1957]] In societies of [[Hunter-gatherer|hunters and gatherers]] like the traditional society of the Australian aboriginal people, the men hunt animals for meat, and the women gather other foods such as [[grain]], [[fruit]] and [[vegetable]]s. One of the reasons for this division of labor was that it is much easier to look after a baby while gathering fruit than while hunting a fast-moving animal. Even when homes were very simple and there were few possessions, men and women did different jobs.
In rural societies, where the main work is [[farming]], women have also taken care of gardens and animals around the house, generally helping men with heavy work when a job needed to be done quickly, usually because of the season.
Examples of the heavy work that a traditional housewife (homemaker) in a ''rural society'' would do are: * Picking fruit when it was ripe for market * Planting rice in a [[rice|paddy field]] * Harvesting and stacking grain * Cutting hay
In rural studies, the word ''housewife'' is occasionally used for a woman who does the majority of the chores within a farm's [[Compound (enclosure)|compound]] as opposed to field and livestock work{{Citation needed|date=January 2012}}.
===Modern society=== A career woman may follow a "[[mommy track]]", or a [[shared earning/shared parenting marriage]].
Regarding [[Family#Size|family size]], a study of three [[Mexico|Mexican]] cities came to the result that there was no significant difference in the number of children in housewife families compared to those where women worked outside of the home part or full-time.<ref>{{cite book | last=Chant | first=Sylvia | title=Women and Survival in Mexican Cities: perspectives on gender, labour markets, and low-income households | publisher=Manchester University Press Distributed in the USA and Canada by St. Martin's Press | location=Manchester, UK; New York, NY, USA | year=1991 | isbn=0-7190-3443-4 | ref=harv}} [https://books.google.com/books?id=bPTPAAAAIAAJ&pg=PA128 Page 128]</ref>
It has become more commonplace for the husband and wife to both be employed outside of the home and for both to share in the "housework" and caring for the children.{{citation needed|date=September 2015}}
Full-time homemakers usually share in the income produced by members of the household who are employed; wage-earners working full-time benefit from the unpaid work provided by the housewife; otherwise, the performance of such work (child care, cooking, housecleaning, teaching, transporting, etc.) could be a household expense.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.chicagoreader.com/chicago/whats-a-wife-worth/Content?oid=871934|title=What's a Wife Worth?|date=17 March 1988|accessdate=17 Oct 2015}}</ref>[[Community property]] states recognize joint ownership of marital property and income, and unless a prenuptial or postnuptial agreement is followed, most marital households in the US operate as a joint financial team and file [[taxes]] jointly.
===Education=== The method, necessity and extent of education of house wives has been debated since at least the 20th century.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Dement|first1=Alice L.|title=Higher Education of the Housewife: Wanted or Wasted?|journal=The Journal of Higher Education|date=1960|volume=31|issue=1 (January)|doi=10.2307/1977571|jstor=1977571|publisher=Ohio State University Press}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Mummy, I want to be a housewife|url=https://www.timeshighereducation.com/news/mummy-i-want-to-be-a-housewife/93431.article|accessdate=8 May 2016|work=Times Higher Education|date=26 April 1996}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|url=http://isites.harvard.edu/fs/docs/icb.topic1114896.files/Najmabadi%201998.pdf|title=Crafting an Educated Housewife in Iran}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.thetimes.co.uk/tto/opinion/columnists/article3485879.ece|title=Highly educated housewives: what an economic waste|date=25 July 2012|work=The Times|accessdate=8 May 2016}}</ref>
==Songs about the housewife's lot== The housewife's tasks have often been the subject of songs. Examples include: "The Housewife's Lament" (from the diary of Sarah Price, Ottawa, Illinois, mid 19th century);<ref>Recorded on: ''The Female Frolic'', Argo ZDA 82 & [[Peggy Seeger|Seeger, P.]] ''Penelope isn't Waiting any More'' Blackthorne BR 1050</ref> "Nine Hours a Day" (1871 English song, anonymous); "A Woman's Work is Never Done"<ref>Recorded on [[Sam Richards (writer)|Staverton Bridge]] SADISC SDL 266</ref> or "A Woman Never Knows When her Day's Work is Done"; "The Labouring Woman"; "How Five and Twenty Shillings were Expended in a Week" (English popular songs); "A Woman's Work" (London music hall song by Sue Pay, 1934).<ref>Kathy Henderson et al., comp. (1979) ''My Song is My Own: 100 women's songs''. London: Pluto; pp. 126-28, 142-43</ref> "The Housewife's Alphabet", by [[Peggy Seeger]], was issued as a Blackthorne Records single with "My Son".<ref>''New City Songster''; vol. 13, Oct. 1977</ref>
== Housewives by country == [[File:Percent women 20-64 years in the workforce in the European Union 2011.png|thumb|300px|Percent of [[women in the workforce]] among all women aged 20 - 64 years in the [[European Union]] in 2011.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.scb.se/statistik/_publikationer/LE0001_2013K02_TI_00_A05TI1302.pdf|title=Ekonomiskt oberoende– långt kvar för EU:s kvinnor|author=Lena Bernhardtz|website=Välfärd, by [[:en:Statistics Sweden|Statistics Sweden]]}} February 2013</ref>]]
===In China=== In [[Imperial era of Chinese history|imperial China]] (excluding periods of the [[Tang dynasty]]), women were bound to homemaking by the doctrines of [[Confucianism]] and cultural norms. Generally, girls did not attend school and, therefore, spent the day doing household chores with their mothers and female relatives (for example, [[cooking]] and [[Housekeeping|cleaning]]). In most cases, the husband was alive and able to work, so the wife was almost always forbidden to take a job and mainly spent her days at home or doing other domestic tasks. As Confucianism spread across [[East Asia]], this social norm was also observed in [[Korea]], [[Japan]] and [[Vietnam]]. As [[foot binding]] became common after the [[Song Dynasty]], many women lost the ability to work outside.
After the founding of the [[Republic of China (1912–1949)|Republic of China]] in 1911, these norms were gradually loosened and many women were able to enter the workforce. Shortly thereafter, a growing number of females began to be permitted to attend schools. Starting with the rule of the [[People's Republic of China]] in 1949, all women were freed from compulsory family roles. During the [[Great Leap Forward]] and [[Cultural Revolution]], some women even worked in fields that were traditionally reserved for males.
In modern China, housewives are no longer as common, especially in the largest cities and other urban areas. Many modern women work simply because one person's income is insufficient to support the family, a decision made easier by the fact that it is common for Chinese grandparents to watch after their grandchildren until they are old enough to go to school. Nonetheless, the number of Chinese housewives has been steadily rising in recent years as China's economy expands.{{dubious|date=February 2017}}
===In India===
In a traditional [[Hindu]] family, the head of the family is the ''Griha Swami'' (Lord of the House) and his wife is the ''Griha Swamini'' (Lady of the House). The [[Sanskrit]] words ''Grihast'' and ''Grihasta'' perhaps come closest to describing the entire gamut of activities and roles undertaken by the homemaker. ''Grih'' is the Sanskrit root for house or home; Grihasta and Grihast are derivatives of this root, as is [[Grihastya]]. The couple lives in the state called ''Grihastashram'' or family system and together they nurture the family and help its members (both young and old) through the travails of life. The woman who increments the family tree (bears children) and protects those children is described as the ''Grihalakshmi'' (the wealth of the house) and ''Grihashoba'' (the glory of the house). The elders of the family are known as ''Grihshreshta''. The husband or wife may engage in countless other activities which may be social, religious, political or economic in nature for the ultimate welfare of the family and society. However, their unified status as joint householders is the nucleus from within which they operate in society. The traditional status of a woman as a homemaker anchors them in society and provides meaning to their activities within the social, religious, political and economic framework of their world. However, as India undergoes modernisation, many women are in employment, particularly in the larger cities such as [[Mumbai]], [[Delhi]], [[Kolkata]], [[Chennai]], [[Hyderabad]], [[Bangalore]] where most women will work. The role of the male homemaker is not traditional in [[India]], but it is socially accepted in [[urban area|urban]] areas. According to one sociologist's study in 2006, twelve percent of unmarried Indian men would consider being a homemaker according to a survey conducted by ''[[Business Today (business magazine)|Business Today]]''.<ref name="life&times">{{cite web|url=http://specials.indiatoday.com/indianmensurvey/Unmarried_Man_partner.php|title=Life & Times of Indian Men|date=July 29, 2009|publisher=Business Today|accessdate=2009-07-30}}</ref> One sociologist, Sushma Tulzhapurkar, called this a shift in Indian society, saying that a decade ago, "it was an unheard concept and not to mention socially unacceptable for men to give up their jobs and remain at home."<ref name="dias">{{cite web|url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/NEWS/City/Bombay-Times/Now-papas-do-what-mamas-did-best-/articleshow/1682154.cms|title=Now papas do what mamas did best!|last=Dias|first=Raul|date=June 26, 2006|publisher=Times of India|accessdate=2009-07-30}}</ref> However, only 22.7 percent of Indian women are part of the [[labor force]], compared to 51.6 percent of men; thus, women are more likely to be caregivers because most do not work outside the home.<ref name="fao">{{cite web|url=http://www.fao.org/sd/wpdirect/WPre0108.htm|title=Asia's women in agriculture, environment and rural production|accessdate=2009-07-30|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140630002611/http://www.fao.org/sd/wpdirect/WPre0108.htm|archivedate=2014-06-30|df=}}</ref>
===In Korea===
====North Korea==== Until around 1990, the [[North Korea]]n state required every able-bodied male to be employed by some [[state enterprise]]. However, some 30% of married women of working age were allowed to stay at home as full-time housewives (less than in some countries in the same region like South Korea, Japan and [[Taiwan]]; more than in the former [[Soviet Union]], [[Mainland China]] and Nordic countries like Sweden, and about the same as in the United States<ref>[http://article.yeeyan.org/view/91830/133129 a Chinese-English translation web (译言网）:Will Chinese women rule the world?]</ref>). In the early 1990s, after an estimated 900,000-3,500,000 people perished in the [[North Korean famine]], the old system began to fall apart. In some cases women began by selling homemade food or household items they could do without. Today at least three-quarters of North Korean market vendors are women. A joke making the rounds in [[Pyongyang]] goes: 'What do a [[husband]] and a pet dog have in common?' Answer: 'Neither works nor earns money, but both are cute, stay at home and can scare away burglars.'<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cuyoo.com/html/guoji/2010/0422/14322.html |author=Andrei Lankov (a professor in South Korea National University)|work= cuyoo.com (Chinese-English Translate Web|title= Pyongyang’s Women Wear the Pants}}</ref>
=== In the United Kingdom === {{expand section|date=February 2013}} [[File:A Day in the Life of a Wartime Housewife- Everyday Life in London, England, 1941 D2366.jpg|thumb|Part of the housework of a London housewife, 1941]] Two British magazines for housewives have been published: ''The Housewife'' (London: Offices of "The Million", 1886[1900]) and ''Housewife'' (London: Hultons, 1939–68).<ref>Held by various libraries in the UK; [http://copac.ac.uk Copac]</ref>
"On a Tired Housewife" is an anonymous poem about the housewife's lot:
<poem> Here lies a poor woman who was always tired, She lived in a house where help wasn't hired: Her last words on earth were: "Dear friends, I am going To where there's no cooking, or washing, or sewing, For everything there is exact to my wishes, For where they don't eat there's no washing of dishes. I'll be where loud anthems will always be ringing, But having no voice I'll be quit of the singing. Don't mourn for me now, don't mourn for me never, I am going to do nothing for ever and ever."<ref>''The Penguin Book of Comic and Curious Verse'', ed. J. M. Cohen. Harmondsworth: Penguin, 1952; p. 31</ref> </poem>
===In the United States=== [[File:Tetra Pak housewife with shopping net, 1950s.jpg|thumb|1950s [[Tetrapak]] advertisement depicting a housewife as a selector and consumer of products]] [[File:HOUSEWIFE IN THE KITCHEN OF HER MOBILE HOME IN ONE OF THE TRAILER PARKS. THE TWO PARKS WERE CREATED IN RESPONSE TO... - NARA - 558298.jpg|thumb|A Minnesota housewife in the kitchen of her mobile home]] About 50% of married US women in 1978 continued to work after giving birth, while in 1997, the number was 61%. The number of housewives increased in the 2000s. With the [[2008 financial crisis]], a decrease in average income made two incomes more attractive, and the percentage of married US women who kept working after they giving birth increased to 69% by 2009.<ref>[http://www.bls.gov/news.release/famee.nr0.htm Employment Characteristics of Families Summary". U.S. Department of Labor. Retrieved 2011-10-22.]</ref><ref>[http://article.yeeyan.org/view/91830/133129 a Chinese-English translation web (译言网: Will Chinese women rule the world?]</ref> As of 2014, according to the Pew Research Center, more than one in four mothers are stay at home in the United States.
Housewives in America were typical in the middle of the 20th century among middle-class and upper-class white families.<ref name=":1">{{Cite news|url=https://longreads.com/2018/03/21/seeking-a-roadmap-for-the-new-american-middle-class/|title=Seeking a Roadmap for the New American Middle Class|last=Gershon|first=Livia|date=2018-03-21|work=Longreads|access-date=2018-04-25|language=en-US}}</ref> Black families, recent immigrants, and other minority groups tended not to benefit from the union wages, government policies, and other factors that led to white wives being able to stay at home during these decades.<ref name=":1" />
A 2005 study estimated that 31 percent of working mothers leave the workplace (for an average of 2.2 years), most often precipitated by the birth of the second child.<ref>Hewlett, S. A., Luce, C. B., Shiller, P. & Southwell, S. (2005, March). The hidden brain drain: Off-ramps and on-ramps in women’s careers. Center for WorkLife. Policy/Harvard Business Review Research. Report, Product no. 9491. Cambridge, MA: Harvard Business School Publishing Corporation.</ref> This gives time to concentrate full-time on child-rearing and to avoid the high cost of child care, particularly through the early years (before school begins at age five). There is considerable variability within the stay-at-home mother population with regard to their intent to return to the paid workforce. Some plan to work from their homes, some will do part-time work, some intend to return to part or full-time work when their children have reached school age, some may increase their skill sets by returning to higher education, and others may find it financially feasible to refrain from entering (or re-entering) the paid workforce. Research has linked feelings of "maternal guilt and separation anxiety" to returning to the workforce.<ref>Rubin, Stacey E., and H. Ray Wooten. "Highly educated stay-at-home mothers: A study of commitment and conflict." ''The Family Journal'' 15.4 (2007): 336-345.</ref>
Similarly, there is considerable variation in the stay-at-home mother's attitude towards domestic work not related to caring for children. Some may embrace a traditional role of housewife, cooking and cleaning in addition to caring for children. Others see their primary role as that of child-care providers, supporting their children's physical, intellectual, emotional, and spiritual development while sharing or outsourcing other aspects of home care.
==History== Although men have generally been thought of as the primary [[breadwinner]]s for families in recent history, the division of labor between men and women in traditional societies required both genders to take an active role in obtaining resources outside the domestic sphere. Prior to discovering agriculture and animal husbandry, predictable food sources were a scarce commodity. To achieve optimal nutrition during this time, it was imperative that both men and women focus their energies on hunting and gathering as many different edible foods as possible to sustain themselves on a daily basis. Lacking the technologies necessary to store and preserve food, it was critical for men and women to seek out and obtain fresh food sources almost continuously. These nomadic tribes used gender differences to their advantage, allowing men and women to use their complementary adaptations and survival strategies to find the most diverse and nutritionally complete foods available. For example, in the context of daily foraging, childcare itself was not a hindrance to women's productivity; rather, performing this task with her children both increased the overall efficiency of the activity (more people participating equals a greater yield of edible roots, berries, nuts and plants), and functioned as an important hands-on lesson in survival skills for each child. By sharing the burden of daily sustenance – and developing specialized gender niches – humans not only ensured their continued survival, but also paved the way for later technologies to evolve and grow through experience.
In the 19th century, more and more women in industrialising countries stopped being homemakers and farm wives and began to undertake paid work in various industries outside the home and away from the family farm, in addition to the work they did at home. At this time many big [[factory|factories]] were set up, first in England then in other European countries and the United States. Many thousands of young women went to work in factories; most factories employed women in roles different from those occupied by men. There were also women who worked at home for low wages while caring for their children at the same time.
[[File:Pierre-Édouard Frère - Child Praying at Mother's Knee - Walters 371330.jpg|thumb|''Child Praying at Mother's Knee''; drawing by [[Pierre Edouard Frère|Pierre-Édouard Frère]]]] [[File:Kök 1950.jpg|thumb|A woman cooks, supervised by a teacher in a domestic economy institute in Stockholm, Sweden, 1950.|alt=En kvinna arbetar i köket, en annan kvinna antecknar och klockar tiden (Rålambsvägen 8 och 10 i Stockholm)]] Being a housewife was only realistic among middle-class and upper-class families. In working-class families, it was typical for women to work. In the 19th century, a third to half of married women in England were recorded in the census as working for outside pay, and some historians believe this to be an undercount.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2014/apr/13/working-women-stay-at-home-wives-myths|title=So wives didn't work in the 'good old days'? Wrong|last=Wilkinson|first=Amanda|date=2014-04-13|website=The Guardian|language=en|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-04-23|df=dmy}}</ref> Among married couples that could afford it, the wife often managed the [[Homemaking|housework]], gardening, cooking, and children without working outside the home. Women were often very proud to be a good homemaker and have their house and children respectably taken care of. Other women, like [[Florence Nightingale]], pursued non-factory professions even though they were wealthy enough that they did not need the income. Some professions open to women were also restricted to unmarried women, e.g., teaching.
In the early 20th century, both world wars ([[World War I]], 1914–18, and [[World War II]], 1939-45) were fought by men from many countries. (There were also special roles in the armed forces carried out by women, e.g. nursing, transport, etc. and in some countries women soldiers also.) While the men were at war, many of their womenfolk went to work to keep the countries running. Women, who were also homemakers, worked in factories, businesses and farms. At the end of both wars, many men had died, and others had returned injured. Some men were able to return to their previous positions, but some women stayed in the workforce as well. In addition to this surge in women entering the workforce, convenience food and technology were also rising in popularity, both of which saved women time that they may have spent performing domestic tasks, and enabled them to instead pursue other interests.<ref>{{cite | last = Maurer | first = Elizabeth | title = "How Highly Processed Foods Liberated 1950s Housewives" | publisher = National Women's History Museum | year = 2017 | url = https://www.womenshistory.org/articles/how-highly-processed-foods-liberated-1950s-housewives}}</ref>
The governments of [[Communist]] countries in the early and middle 20th century such as the Soviet Union and China encouraged married women to keep working after giving birth. There were very few housewives in Communist countries until [[Post-communism|free market economic reform]] in the 1990s, which led to a resurgence in the number of housewives. Conversely, in the [[Western World]] of the 1950s, many women quit their jobs to be housewives after giving birth. Only 11% of married women in the US kept working after giving birth.<ref>[http://www.doc88.com/p-57886790766.html In the kitchen debate in 1959: Nixon said American housewives are happier than the Soviet Union working women]</ref>
In the 1960s in western countries, it was becoming more accepted for a woman to work until she got married, when it was widely held that she should stop work and be a housewife. Many women believed that this was not treating men and women [[gender equality|equally]] and that women should do whatever jobs they were able to do, whether they were married or not. ''[[The Feminine Mystique]]'', a 1963 book by [[Betty Friedan]] which is widely credited with sparking the beginning of [[second-wave feminism]] in the United States, discussed among other things the lives of housewives from around the United States who were unhappy despite living in material comfort and being married with children.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.enotes.com/feminine-mystique/summary |title=The Feminine Mystique Summary |publisher=Enotes.com |accessdate=2011-02-18}}</ref><ref name="nytimes2006">[https://www.nytimes.com/2006/02/05/national/05friedan.html Betty Friedan, Who Ignited Cause in 'Feminine Mystique,' Dies at 85] - ''The New York Times,'' February 5, 2006.</ref> At this time, many women were becoming more educated. As a result of this increased education, some women were able to earn more than their husbands. In very rare cases, the husband would remain at home to raise their young children while the wife worked. In 1964 a US stamp was issued honoring homemakers for the 50th anniversary of the [[Smith-Lever Act]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nwhm.org/online-exhibits/stamps/homemakers.html|title=Leaving Their Stamp on History|publisher=|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150906064904/https://www.nwhm.org/online-exhibits/stamps/homemakers.html|archivedate=2015-09-06|df=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://arago.si.edu/category_2034154.html|title=Arago: Homemakers Issue|publisher=}}</ref>
In the late 20th century, in many countries it became harder for a family to live on a single wage. Subsequently, many women were required to return to work following the birth of their children. However, the number of male homemakers began gradually increasing in the late 20th century, especially in developed Western nations. In 2010, the number of male homemakers had reached its highest point of 2.2 million.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.pewsocialtrends.org/2014/06/05/growing-number-of-dads-home-with-the-kids/|title=Growing Number of Dads Home with the Kids|last=Livingston|first=Gretchen|website=Pew Research Center’s Social & Demographic Trends Project|access-date=2016-03-22}}</ref> Though the role is subject to many [[stereotype]]s, and men may have difficulties accessing parenting benefits, communities, and services targeted at mothers, it became more socially acceptable by the 2000s.<ref>[[Andrea Doucet]], 2006. [https://books.google.com/books?id=G1p3v2soHToC&lpg=PP1&ots=PKa-ClKQUJ&dq=andrea%20doucet%20do%20men%20mother%3F&pg=PP1#v=onepage&q&f=false Do Men Mother?] Toronto, ON: University of Toronto Press.</ref> The male homemaker was more regularly portrayed in the media by the 2000s, especially in the United States. However, in some regions of the world the male homemaker remains culturally unacceptable.

{{Other uses|King's College (disambiguation){{!}}King's College}} {{Infobox university | name = King's College | native_name = किङ्स कलेज | native_name_lang = ne | image = | image_upright = | image_alt = | caption = | latin_name = | other_name = <!--or, other_names--> | former_name = <!--or, former_names--> | motto = Architecting future | motto_lang = en | mottoeng = | top_free_label = | top_free = | type = [[Private university|Private]] | established = {{start date|2003}} | closed = <!-- {{end date|YYYY}} --> | founder = | parent = | affiliation = Westcliff University | religious_affiliation = | academic_affiliation = | endowment = | budget = | officer_in_charge = | chairman = | chairperson = | chancellor = | president = | vice-president = | superintendent = | provost = | vice_chancellor = | rector = | principal = | dean = | director = Narottam Aryal<ref name="myrepublica"/> | head_label = | head = | academic_staff = 38 | administrative_staff = | students = | undergrad = | postgrad = | doctoral = | other = | address = Babarmahal | city = [[Kathmandu]] | state = | province = [[Province No. 3]] | country = [[Nepal]] | postcode = <!--or, postalcode or zipcode--> | coordinates ={{coord|27.6890|85.3280 |type:edu |display=inline}} | campus = [[urban area|Urban]] | language = [[English language|English]] | free_label = | free = | free_label2 = | free2 = | colors = <!--or, colours= --> | athletics = | sports = | athletics_nickname = <!--or, sports_nickname= --> | sporting_affiliations = | mascot = <!--or, mascots= --> | sports_free_label = | sports_free = | sports_free_label2 = | sports_free2 = | website = {{URL|http://www.kingscollege.edu.np/}} | logo = | logo_size = | logo_alt = | footnotes = }} '''King's College''' ({{lang-ne|किङ्स कलेज}}) is a private business school situated at Babarmahal, Kathmandu, Nepal. It is affiliated to Westcliff University, California.<ref name="educatenepal">{{cite web|url=http://www.educatenepal.com/promotion/detail/admission-open-for-mba-and-mba-entrepreneurship-from-kings-college|title=Admission open for MBA and MBA Entrepreneurship from King's College, Best MBA in Nepal, Studying MBA in Kathmandu, Top Ranked Colleges Nepal|website=www.educatenepal.com}}</ref><ref name="edusanjal">{{cite web|url=https://edusanjal.com/college/kings-college/|title=Kings College BabarMahal, Bijuli Bazar Kathmandu|website=Edusanjal}}</ref><ref name="collegesnepal">{{cite web|url=http://www.collegesnepal.com/kings-college/|title=Kings College Babarmahal Kathmandu, BBA, MBA - Location Phone at Colleges Nepal|website=Colleges Nepal}}</ref>
==History== It was established as an A level institute in 2003. Later in 2009, the college extended other higher level studies as [[Bachelor of Business Administration]] (BBA) and [[Master's in Business Administration]] (MBA).<ref name="edusanjal"/><ref name="collegesnepal"/><ref name="AboutKings">{{cite web|url=http://www.kingscollege.edu.np/about/|title=About - Kings College|website=www.kingscollege.edu.np}}</ref>
===2010-2015=== In 2014, the college received awards for third best business school of Nepal and second best graduate business school (MBA) of Nepal.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.newbusinessage.com/MagazineArticles/view/933|title=Newbiz Salutes the B-School Excellence - New Business Age - monthly business magazine in English published from Nepal|website=www.newbusinessage.com}}</ref> The college took the affiliation of Westcliff University, [[California]], an accredited American University in 2015.<ref name="myrepublica">{{cite web|url=http://admin.myrepublica.com/society/story/27806/king-s-college-takes-affiliation-of-accredited-westcliff-university.html|title=My Republica - King's College takes affiliation of accredited Westcliff University|first=|last=REPUBLICA|date=|website=myrepublica.com|accessdate=2 March 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bizmandu.com/content/-13146.html|title=किङ्स कलेज अब अमेरिकाको वेस्टक्लिफ विश्वविद्यालयको सम्बन्धनमा, विदेशकै गुणस्तरमा शिक्षा :: BIZMANDU.COM|first=|last=bizmandu.com|website=www.bizmandu.com}}</ref>
===Partnership with Yunus Social Business Center=== In 2016, the college has entered into partnership with [[Yunus Social Business – Global Initiatives|Yunus Center]] of [[Dhaka]] at the premise of [[Grameen Bank]]. The chief signatory were Director of King's College Narottam Aryal and Nobel Prize Winner [[Muhammad Yunus]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://kathmandupost.ekantipur.com/news/2016-11-25/kings-college-yunus-centre-join-hands.html|title=King’s College, Yunus Centre join hands|author=|date=|website=ekantipur.com|accessdate=2 March 2018}}</ref>The purpose of the partnership was to establish Yunus Social Business Center in Nepal by the King's College.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bizkhabar.com/education/20818.html|title=किङ्स कलेज र युनुसबीच साझेदारी, नेपालमा युनुस सामाजिक उद्यमशिलता केन्द्रको स्थापना|date=24 November 2016|publisher=www.bizkhabar.com}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.abhiyan.com.np/2016/11/25/87962|title=किङ्स कलेज र युनुस सेण्टरबीच सहकार्यात्मक सहमति - गृहपृष्ठ|author=|date=|website=www.abhiyan.com.np|accessdate=2 March 2018}}</ref><ref>https://corporatenepal.com/2016/11/6611</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://merolagani.com/NewsDetail.aspx?newsID=28922|title=किङ्स कलेज र युनुस सेन्टरबीच उद्यमशिलता केन्द्र स्थापना गर्न समझदारी|publisher=Mero Lagani}}</ref>
===2017-present=== The college took part in KAF Corporate Quiz in 2017.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://ratopati.prixa.org/story/26450?flavour=mobile|title=केएएफ २०१७ : कर्पोरेट क्वीजको उपाधि एपेक्सलाई|publisher=Ratopati}}</ref> On 7 July 2017, the college celebrated their first convocation with 130 MBA graduates and 76 BBA graduates. The program was attended by then Deputy Prime Minister and Education Minister [[Gopal Man Shrestha]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.newbusinessage.com/Articles/view/6179|title=King’s College Celebrates First Convocation - New Business Age - monthly business magazine in English published from Nepal|author=|date=|website=www.newbusinessage.com|accessdate=2 March 2018}}</ref> On September 2017, the college had announced to host 16th International Entrepreneurship Forum (IEF) conference at Hotel Radisson. The theme of the program was ''Sustainable Entrepreneurship and Development''<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.myrepublica.com/news/27336/|title=King’s College to host IEF conference|publisher=[[MyRepublica]]}}</ref> and the partner in association was Essex Business School, London.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://english.onlinekhabar.com/2017/09/11/406466.html|title=International Entrepreneurship Forum Conference to be held in Kathmandu – OnlineKhabar|website=english.onlinekhabar.com}}</ref><ref>https://glocalkhabar.com/featured/kings-college-set-host-16th-international-entrepreneurship-forum-ief-conference-sept-14/</ref> On 27 February 2018, the college released first issue of ''International Journal of Entrepreneurship and Economic Issues'' at a program in Hotel Radisson. The in-house journal focused on developing strong research culture.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.myrepublica.com/news/37131/|title=King's College launches in-house journal|publisher=[[MyRepublica]]}}</ref> In 2018, the college has organized second celebration programme called ''Hamro Utsav''. The programme is focused on stock market challenge, social media marketing, business planning, human resources management and quiz shows. Additional programmes were mad aids, short movie, themetic photography, battle of bands, junk arts, college icon, dance competition, event planning, business exhibition, drawing competitions.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://thehimalayantimes.com/entertainment/events/kings-college-host-hamro-utsav/|title=King's College to host Hamro Utsav|author=|date=26 February 2017|website=thehimalayantimes.com|accessdate=2 March 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://sushasannews.com/corporate/4249|title=किङ्स कलेजले दोस्रो उत्सव गर्दै|website=sushasannews.com}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hamrokalam.com/2017/02/26/%E0%A4%B9%E0%A4%BE%E0%A4%AE%E0%A5%8D%E0%A4%B0%E0%A5%8B-%E0%A4%89%E0%A4%A4%E0%A5%8D%E0%A4%B8%E0%A4%B5-%E0%A4%86%E0%A4%AF%E0%A5%8B%E0%A4%9C%E0%A4%A8%E0%A4%BE-%E0%A4%97%E0%A4%A6%E0%A5%88-%E0%A4%95/|title=हाम्रो उत्सव आयोजना गदै किङ्स कलेज|website=www.hamrokalam.com}}</ref> ==Campus== {{empty section|date=April 2018}}
==Courses== The college offers [[Bachelor of Business Administration]] (BBA), [[Master's in Business Administration]] (MBA),<ref name="edusanjal"/> MBA entrepreneurship,<ref name="myrepublica"/> MBA in eBusiness and MBA for professionals (MBA pro).<ref>http://www.kingscollege.edu.np/programs/</ref>
==Notable alumni== {{empty section|date=April 2018}}
==See also== *[[Nepal Open University]] *[[Kathmandu College of Management]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== *[http://www.kingscollege.edu.np/ Official Website]

{{cleanup|date=November 2010}}
'''Metallurgical failure analysis''' is the process by which a metallurgist determines the mechanism that has caused a metal component to fail. Typical failure modes involve various types of corrosion and mechanical damage. It has been estimated that the direct annual [cost of corrosion] alone in the United States was $276 billion, approximately 3.1% of GDP, in 1998. Corrosion costs have continued to skyrocket and total corrosion costs now are greater than $1 trillion annually in the United States as of 2012.
Metal components fail as a result of the environmental conditions to which they are exposed to as well as the mechanical stresses that they experience. Often a combination of both environmental conditions and stress will cause failure.
Metal components are designed to withstand the environment and stresses that they will be subjected to. The design of a metal component involves not only a specific elemental composition but also specific manufacturing process such as heat treatments, machining processes, etc.… The huge arrays of different metals that result all have unique physical properties. Specific properties are designed into metal components to make them more robust to various environmental conditions. These differences in physical properties will exhibit unique failure modes. A metallurgical failure analysistakes into account as much of this information as possible during analysis. The end goal of failure analysis is to provide a determination of the root cause and a solution to any underlying problems to prevent future failures.<ref>http://www.g2mtlabs.com/failure-analysis/what-is-failure-analysis/ G2MT Labs - "What is Failure Analysis?"</ref>
Analysis of a failed part can be done using [[destructive testing]] or [[non-destructive testing]]. Destructive testing involves removing a metal component from service and sectioning the component for analysis. Destructive testing gives the failure analyst the ability to conduct the analysis in a [[laboratory]] setting and perform tests on the material that will ultimately destroy the component. Non destructive testing is a test method that allows certain physical properties of metal to be examined without taking the samples completely out of service. NDT is generally used to detect failures in components before the component fails catastrophically.
There is no standardized list of metallurgical [[failure mode]]s and different metallurgists might use a different name for the same failure mode. The Failure Mode Terms listed below are those accepted by [[ASTM]],<ref>“Standard Terms Relating to Corrosion and Corrosion Testing” (G 15), Annual Book of ASTM Standards, ASTM, Philadelphia, PA. </ref> [[ASM International (society)|ASM]],<ref>ASM-International Metals Handbook, Ninth Edition, Corrosion, ASM-International, Metals Park, OH </ref> and/or [[National Association of Corrosion Engineers|NACE]]<ref>NACE-International NACE Basic Corrosion Course, NACE-International, Houston, TX</ref> as distinct metallurgical failure mechanisms.
== Metallurgical Failure Modes Caused By Corrosion and Stress ==
*[[Stress Corrosion Cracking]]<ref>M&M Engineering Conduit Fall 2007 “Chloride Pitting and Stress Corrosion Cracking of Stainless Steel Alloys,” {{cite web |url=http://mmengineering.com/pdf%20files/Conduit-Fall%202007.pdf |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2010-08-20 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110714104413/http://mmengineering.com/pdf%20files/Conduit-Fall%202007.pdf |archivedate=2011-07-14 |df= }} </ref> *[[Corrosion Fatigue]] *Caustic Cracking (ASTM term) *[[Caustic embrittlement|Caustic Embrittlement]] (ASM term) *Stress Corrosion (NACE term) *[[Sulfide stress cracking|Sulfide Stress Cracking]] (ASM, NACE term) *Stress Accelerated Corrosion (NACE term) *Hydrogen Stress Cracking (ASM term) *Hydrogen Assisted Stress Corrosion Cracking (ASM term)
==Metallurgical Failure Modes Caused By Stress==
*[[Fatigue (material)|Fatigue]] (ASTM, ASM term) *[[Mechanical overload (engineering)|Mechanical Overload]] *[[Creep (deformation)|Creep]] *[[Rupture (engineering)|Rupture]] *Cracking (NACE term) *Embrittlement
==Metallurgical Failure Modes Caused by Corrosion==
*[[Erosion corrosion|Erosion Corrosion]] *Oxygen Pitting *[[Hydrogen embrittlement|Hydrogen Embrittlement]] *Hydrogen Induced Cracking (ASM term) *Corrosion Embrittlement (ASM term) *Hydrogen Disintegration (NACE term) *Hydrogen Assisted Cracking (ASM term) *Hydrogen Blistering *Corrosion
==References==
<references/>
{{DEFAULTSORT:Metallurgical Failure Analysis}} [[Category:Mechanical engineering]] [[Category:Materials science]] [[Category:Metallurgy]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox company |name = MusicWriter |logo = NoteStation.jpg |logo_size = 300px |foundation=1989 |founder=[[Jon Monday]] and Lawrence Heller |location=[[Los Gatos, CA]], USA |area_served=Global |industry=[[Sheet Music]] and [[MIDI]] |products=NoteStation }}
'''MusicWriter''' was founded in 1989 by music industry veterans [[Jon Monday]] and Larry Heller to develop and market NoteStation, a kiosk-based retail "point-of-sale manufacturing" system for the distribution and printing of [[sheet music]]. Besides having a very large library of songs across all music genres, the NoteStation was able to print the [[sheet music]] on demand in any key, as selected by the customer. This reduced the need for retailers to carry a large selection of physical inventory, which was usually only printed in one key.
Early in the MusicWriter's history [[Warner Bros.]] Music and [[Thorn EMI]], the two largest music publishers in the world, invested in the company and became board members. The company then was able to sign most of the major music publishers to offer their titles through the system.
MusicWriter was among the first applications of the new distribution paradigm of "Mass Customization" or "Point-of-Sale Manufacturing", where a retailer is able to offer a very large selection of a product, with virtually no inventory, and manufacture the customized product on the spot for a customer. This trend was documented in B. Joseph Pine II’s 1993 book, ''Mass Customization, The New Frontier in Business Competition'' published by Harvard Business School Press.
The company expanded its features to include producing [[MIDI]] files on demand and online ordering of music products from distributors.{{ref|Article1}}
The company was featured on CNN TV and written about in Fortune Magazine, Business Week, USA Today, San Francisco Examiner, San Jose Mercury News, and Popular Science.
Due to the major print music companies that fought against the technologies, in 1999 MusicWriter went bankrupt as online technology emerged and the decline of [[sheet music]] retailers made the in-store technology obsolete. However, years later online versions of the technology were introduced by other companies, such as SheetMusicDirect.com, MusicNotes.com, and SheetMusicPlus.com.
==External links== *[http://money.cnn.com/magazines/fortune/fortune_archive/1991/11/04/75692/index.htm Article in Fortune Magazine about MusicWriter] *[http://www.businessweek.com/archives/1992/b327169.arc.htm Article in Business Week about Kiosk products, which features NoteStation] *[http://www.iht.com/articles/1992/09/19/topi_3.php Article in the International Herald Times about NoteStation and MusicWriter] *[https://www.entrepreneur.com/tradejournals/article/print/9372942.html Article in Entrepreneur.com] *[http://www.svcn.com/archives/saratoganews/08.07.96/kiosks.html Article in Saratoga News about MusicWriter] *[http://www.musicnotes.com/default.asp?ca=0 MusicNotes.com] *[http://www.sheetmusicdirect.com SheetMusicDirect.com] *[http://www.dsmusic.com DSMusic.com] *[http://www.sheetmusicplus.com/ SheetMusicPlus.com]
==References==
#{{note|Article1}} [http://svcn.com/archives/saratoganews/08.07.96/kiosks.html Article in Saratoga News Reviewing company history and products]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Musicwriter}} [[Category:Musical notation]] [[Category:Defunct companies based in California]] [[Category:Companies disestablished in 1999]]
